title.en-US: How to quickly perform a syntax check of a JavaScript file

body.en-US:
Recently I came across [a tweet](https://twitter.com/RReverser/status/913779338092466176) by [Ingvar Stepanyan](https://twitter.com/RReverser). He shared the `--check` flag for executing JavaScript files in Node.js. I didn't know about this option.

```
$ node --check some.js

$ node --check some-invalid.js
/Users/stefanjudis/test.js:3
});
^
SyntaxError: Unexpected token }
  at checkScriptSyntax (bootstrap_node.js:457:5)
  at startup (bootstrap_node.js:153:11)
  at bootstrap_node.js:575:3
```

What `--check` enables is a quick check for syntax errors of a JavaScript file without actually executing it. This can be very handy when you're transforming code and just want to make sure the transformation result is valid JavaScript.

On that note: I came accross the [vm module](https://nodejs.org/api/vm.html) which was mentioned in the replies to the tweet. The `vm` module is part of Node core and you can use it to evaluate/execute JavaScript in a sandboxed environment which you control, too.

So far I didn't need this module but you can use it to evaluate and syntax check JavaScript files from within your scripts.

```javascript
const vm = require('vm');
const script = new vm.Script('var a =');
```

The constructor of `vm.Script` throws an exceptions if there are any syntax errors. 

This module looks quite interesting. So, if you're dealing with generated code you might want to check it out. ;)

title.en-US: The for accessibility required `caption` element in HTML  tables

body.en-US:
I'm sitting at the airport in Bangkok right now (yeah vacation!!!) and am reading [an article](http://adrianroselli.com/2017/11/hey-its-still-ok-to-use-tables.html) by [Adrian Roselli](https://twitter.com/aardrian) on tables regarding accessibility. It can not be that hard to build an accessible table. It's just the `table` element including other `th`, `tr` and `td` elements, right? Not quite... The article goes into beautiful detail on what it means to build an accessible table, and in the first few paragraphs of it, it already included something that was new to me â€“ the `caption` element in tables. ```html
Populations of cities
City Population
``` `caption` is one element you don't see "in the wild" very often. [The spec ](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/tables.html#the-caption-element) defines it as follows: > [...] the first element child of a table element. > The caption element represents the title of the table that is its parent, if it has a parent and that is a table element. Defining a title and some additional information for a table makes total sense to me, and more surprising than its rare usage is only that the `caption` element even has its own mention in the [techniques for WCAG 2.0](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/H39.html). ðŸ˜² That said, my next `table` definitely includes a `caption` element.

## this is the tutorial

Stefan started programming 7 years ago and quickly fell in love with web performance, new technologies, and accessibility.

He worked for several startups in Berlin and is now with Contentful to tell the world how an API-first CMS can make you a bit happier.

He is also a curator of the web performance online resource Perf Tooling, organizer of the Web Performance Meetup Berlin, contributes to a variety of open source projects and enjoys sharing nerdy discoveries.
